Similarly, such aid must in no way prejudice the annual accounts of the Member States; everything must be financed from the Union's own resources, a concept — that of own resources — that will undoubtedly take on greater importance as the coming crisis unfolds.  In the midst of a world in which nationalisms, easy speeches with nothing behind it that supports them and the lack of long-term plans are succeeding, Europe can once again be that beacon of wisdom and long-term reference for other countries, as it has always been.

name: Anna-Michelle ASIMAKOPOULOU
text: Writing. – We support Mrs von der Leyen's proposal to create the European Recovery Fund, which is an important step in the right direction. Eu Member States now need more inclusive financial aid than ever before with speed and flexible procedures. The symmetrical nature of the crisis and the depth of the coming recession leave no room for sluciers. The pandemic knocked on everyone's door, but unfortunately for some its effects will be heavier, without fault. For example, Member States such as Greece, which has only recently begun to emerge from a long-term budgetary crisis, where the economy relies heavily on tourism, obviously need and deserve more support from the new European Recovery Package. The criteria for allocating funding should include the level of recession caused by the pandemic as a percentage of GDP, the level of unemployment and the general state of the economy of each Member State. The criteria for allocating funds from the European Recovery Fund must be fair and take into account the specificities and needs of each Member State. Only in this way will the European Union show its solidarity in practice.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. From a French point of view, the recovery plan is a real scam, since France is once again a net contributor - as it is, moreover, a long-standing contributor to the European budget.  This is a reminder of the pitfalls of this European Union, built around a small number of States able to make a financial contribution. This imbalance will only become more pronounced with the departure of the United Kingdom and the planned enlargement to the Western Balkans. There is no doubt that the next negotiations between Member States will be perilous.  On the other hand, it is unacceptable that the European Union should take advantage of a crisis situation to take on new prerogatives and resources in defiance of the fierce opposition of public opinion in some Member States. In the words of Madame von der Leyen, the sea snake of the digital tax is re-emerging.  It is therefore illusory to see this recovery plan as a new impetus for the European Union, since it will only sharpen the existing divisions between the North, the East and the South. There can be no union between such disparate states, and the next wave of enlargement will soon have to underline this evidence again.

name: Milan BRGLEZ
text: Writing. – The Commission's recovery plan, within the structure of the next MFF, is a solid proposal for a compromise, with a macro-union level, between the political aspirations of Member States pursuing a more solidarity-based approach and those groups that base their demands on conditionality.  From this point of view, I welcome the ratio between the estimated volume of grants and loans, with the grant representing a larger share (EUR 500 billion) of the total envelope of EUR 750 billion. I also welcome the fact that conditionality has been dominated by political priorities that direct financial flows towards green transition, digital transformation and strengthening social resilience, which can be seen as ensuring adequate social and health systems in the Member States. It is also commendable that, in this way, the Commission has taken the substantive orientation of parliament's previous two resolutions into account in this way. However, from the micro-level point of view of some Member States, it surprises and raises some concerns about the unfavourable relationship between loans and grants, which, in the case of Slovenia, unlike the ratio of these two components to the EU as a whole, is actually equivalent.  It is therefore all the more important to be careful, careful and economical in the planning of national programmes for the absorption and use of these funds, and the adequacy of fiscal policies, in order to also prevent a slip into a recession due to borrowing and additional exposure of the most vulnerable groups of the population.

name: Joachim Stanisław BRUDZIŃSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Today's extraordinary plenary session of the European Parliament was convened to start a discussion, together with the Commission and the European Council, on a recovery package for the EU. Millions of Europeans are waiting for real help in this unique situation. They are waiting not so much for declarations as for specific tools that they will be able to use to save their entire lives. The realities around us clearly show us that nothing is given to us once and for all, and the sense of security today is far from what we enjoyed earlier this year.  We must return together as close as possible to the state we were in before the current pandemic, and that alone is a huge challenge. However, this is what European citizens expect. Economic security is extremely important. We cannot allow an economic collapse both in our countries and in the EU as a whole. It will certainly be necessary to review the priorities of the Union budget, especially in order to be prepared for similar situations in the near future.  We hope that the declarations made by Mrs von der Leyen, who today calls for the rejection of prejudices and stereotypes, will be real. Unfortunately, my country has experienced such discrimination many times so far and is still experiencing it, precisely in this edifice and in this institution. May the current common challenges help to change this.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. With its resolutions of 17 April and 15 May 2020, the European Parliament called on the Commission to present a massive package of measures and investments for recovery and reconstruction, in support of the European economy. The unprecedented economic and social crisis, triggered by the Covid-19 pandemic, in fact, represents the most difficult moment for Europe in the last seventy years, and therefore requires immediate responses that rise to the challenges we face. The Commission is today proposing the 'Next Generation EU', a new 750 billion recovery instrument, in addition to the 1100 billion of the new MFF and other instruments, for a recovery commitment of 2400 billion in total. This is an ambitious plan, which shows an awareness that no Member State can tackle this serious crisis on its own and therefore the need for genuine European solidarity, and which also recognises Parliament's role in dealing with the emergency. Negotiations on this proposal must now take place under the banner of the urgency recognised by the Croatian Presidency, so that it can immediately meet the needs and needs of citizens, workers and businesses, ensure social cohesion and promote rapid and sustainable recovery and development.

name: Johan DANIELSSON
text: Written. The Corona pandemic has shaken Europe and the rest of the world. There is no doubt that together we must work together to get Europe back on its feet. If there is one thing that this crisis has shown, it is that alone is not strong. It is urgent, and targeted action needs to be made. The European Commission has now presented a gigantic recovery plan to meet the needs of the Member States. Regardless of the final size of the Recovery Fund, it is important that resources are put to the right measures. We do not just need investment, we need smart investments. In order for the recovery plan to provide clear added value, it needs to focus on social and sustainable investment. In order to take responsibility for future generations, it is crucial that the recovery plan prioritises climate change. We need to ensure that the money is used to reduce the carbon footprint of our transport strains regardless of the type of traffic. Last but not least, we must ensure that European funds do not fall into the hands of authoritarian regimes. Not one euro of this money should be paid to countries that violate the rule of law and fundamental democratic values.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: Writing. – Europe is facing one of the worst crises since its inception, so a strong response is crucial for a speedy recovery.  I am pleased with the Commission's proposal to propose an additional €750 billion to deal with the crisis. The money will primarily be used to strengthen existing EU programmes. I am particularly pleased that the compromise proposal is also good for Slovenia, which will be more than €5 billion from the funds. I also welcome the historic decision to finance eu debt on its own through bonds and finance debt through new own funds such as carbon and digital tax. But I'm afraid the new own resources won't be sufficient. For many years, the Socialists and Democrats have also been in favour of introducing a European financial transaction tax, a single taxation of capital, especially multinationals, and the definitive abolition of tax havens and capital of tax-friendly regimes, which would bring additional much needed resources to both the European and national budgets.  The commitments on a just Europe to the people, and not to the capital that we have been advocating for many years in the SD, have become more urgent than ever with this crisis. However, we must not allow additional borrowing to be passed on to people or overburden future generations.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: in writing. – The presentation of "Next Generation EU", a plan of 750 billion euros, of which 500 non-profit, is not only an important signal to combat the Coronavirus emergency is also an historic result for Europe and For Italy, to which the largest part of the resources should be allocated. The European Commission's response represents the evolution of the proposal put forward at the time by Italy, on the initiative of prime minister Giuseppe Conte, who from the beginning asked Europe for an ambitious plan, capable of truly responding to the serious crisis due to the contingent and exceptional historical moment we are experiencing. A plan in which aid to the countries and sectors most affected by the pandemic translated into the best and least selfish of solutions. It contains concrete proposals and objectives historically dear to the 5 Star Movement: Green New Deal, energy transition, digitalization. The final word now rests with the European Council. The health, social and economic crisis due to the Coronavirus requires a tight deadline for negotiations and I hope that solidarity and the union of intentions prevail in the Council, even on the part of those countries, which still today, are calling for measures and solutions that go only in the direction of lending.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. – From a Hungarian point of view, it is a success that the proposal is that the new Recovery Instrument would not be created at the expense of regional development programmes and the common agricultural policy. At the same time, two thirds of the Member States, including Hungary, are well founded on the new proposal, which is almost unchanged from the previous proposals. Hungary has achieved outstanding economic success in recent years and is at the forefront of the management of the epidemic. It would be unjustified if we could not benefit sufficiently from recovery resources because, on the one hand, we have successfully managed the epidemic and, on the other hand, we have reduced our public debt for many years through our disciplined fiscal policy. As with cohesion policy, it is important, in the case of the Recovery Instrument, to take into account differences in economic development between Member States and the state of the economic sectors affected by the crisis when allocating resources.  Poorer Member States should not fund the richer ones. The Eur 750 billion of the Recovery Facility will be raised by the European Commission by borrowing long-term loans. The loan will be repaid by the Member States over a period of 30 years, in proportion to their payments to the EU framework budget. Hungary to repay EUR 7.5 billion of the 750 billion debt with a 1 % contribution rate. Compared to this debt, it is unacceptable that our country would receive a grant of only EUR 8.1 billion, which is barely above its amount.

name: Enikő GYŐRI
text: Writing. – An ambitious joint budget and Recovery Instrument are needed to combat the crisis caused by the epidemic and to boost our economies. It is important that the rules of the game can only be changed by consensus; the introduction of new conditions can only be decided with full agreement. The Recovery Instrument should come from additional resources and should not undersking traditional policies such as cohesion or agricultural policy. Cohesion policy is a key element in the proper functioning of the internal market; there is no competitiveness without reducing development gaps, so it is important that its funding is not reduced. Hungary leading the way in dealing with the epidemic and its effects. As a result, the crisis caused by the coronavirus is expected to hit the Hungarian economy less than the EU average. At the same time, it would be unjustified if central and eastern European Member States could not benefit sufficiently from the resources because, on the one hand, they successfully managed the epidemic and, on the other hand, reduced their public debt for many years through their disciplined fiscal policies. All countries have been affected by the crisis; it is important that they also benefit from the Recovery Facility in a fair manner under the same conditions, be they Member States belonging to the euro area or outside the euro area. Poorer Member States should not fund the richer ones. As regards the objectives of the Recovery Instrument, in addition to the transition to an environmentally friendly economy and digitalisation, priority should also be given to the development of the missing transport and energy infrastructure, particularly in central and eastern European regions.

name: Robert HAJŠEL
text: Writing. – The European Commission presented a multiannual financial framework with a new 'next generation EU' instrument is a huge chance for countries such as Slovakia to embark on a path of modernisation, while also getting more money for it than they could have hoped recently. I believe that, despite the initial opposition of some states to the allocation of guarantors, as well as the increase in funding for the various EU programmes, we will ultimately be able to approve this proposal, at least in similar figures, not only in the EP, but also in the Council before the summer. It is high time that the EU showed its action, decisiveness and solidarity and did not disappoint its citizens, who did not like the Union's weak commitment at the beginning of the corona crisis. As shadow rapporteur for the Just Transition Fund, I will try to promote that all countries have equal access to money from these instruments, and the main criterion for allocating this money is the decline in economic activity as a result of the corona crisis. In fact, even countries such as Slovakia, which have not been so severely affected by the coronavirus, are also facing a deep economic recession as a result of the preventive measures taken. Several sectors of the economy, such as the automotive industry or also tourism, but especially small and medium-medium-back entrepreneurs and sole traders, will not get out of a huge downturn without European help. That is why such mobilisation of European money is more than necessary.

name: Patryk JAKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The European Union has never faced a greater challenge than COVID-19. It can be said that, compared to the current situation, the recent economic crisis has not actually affected Europe. Today, the whole world is in crisis, and where our continent will be depends on the decision of the European Union.  We need bold decisions and the biggest economic plan after World War II. The pace of action now depends on whether we return quickly to the pre-epidemic state or whether we are waiting for many years of reconstruction. Ideological disputes and wasting time on artificial problems must come to the fore. The EU must return to its economic roots, as our citizens expect. Both non-repayable maintenance grants for European companies and loans for new investments are needed.

name: Karol KARSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The Reconstruction Fund will play an important role in the economic recovery of the European Union following the on arrival of a crisis of unprecedented proportions. Given the impact of the crisis on Member States' economies, it is essential that the Reconstruction Fund is properly planned and that appropriate spending priorities are set. Although the economic shock caused by the pandemic affects all Member States, it should be borne in mind that the economic structures of these countries are very different. For this reason, the EU's economic response must not be limited to arbitrarily selected sectors and universal solutions, but must be calibrated for each Member State. It is also crucial for the economic future of The Member States to set appropriate spending priorities, which should be defined on the basis of a comprehensive assessment taking into account not only the direct effects of the pandemic, but also the long-term challenges and economic needs. Convergence, cohesion, inclusivity, solidarity and resilience should be the guiding principles for economic recovery. It should also highlight the ongoing parallel work on the Multiannual Financial Framework 2021-2027. It is necessary to maintain a coherent convergence policy between the Multiannual Financial Framework and those under the Reconstruction Funds, so that Member States are not burdened with costs disproportionate to the size of their economies.

name: Łukasz KOHUT
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The proposal adopted today by the European Commission for further financial assistance for the reconstruction of the European economy is a step in the right direction. President von der Leyen stressed in her speech a very important thing – we have a European economy. The single market means that the European economy is not a simple sum of national economies, it is a completely new quality. That's a lot more. The success of the economic projects in one country has an impact on other countries. The labour market on one side of the border affects the labour market on the other side of the border. The European economy is a federal structure, here borders are only lines on the map. That is why the plan for its reconstruction must be common. And it must also be very ambitious. We cannot save on it – the cost of non-action would be much higher. I am therefore pleased with the proposal to allocate an additional EUR 750 billion to the European economy. I am also pleased with the announcement of the extension of the Union's own budget revenue catalogue. This is one of the tools for federalising Europe, a process that is logical, natural and inevitable for the Union. If we want a truly secure and prosperous Union, not an organism torn apart by national selfishness.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. – From a Hungarian point of view, it is a success that the proposal is that the new Recovery Instrument would not be created at the expense of regional development programmes and the common agricultural policy. At the same time, two thirds of the Member States, including Hungary, are well founded on the new proposal, which is almost unchanged from the previous proposals. Hungary has achieved outstanding economic success in recent years and is at the forefront of the management of the epidemic. It would be unjustified if we could not benefit sufficiently from recovery resources because, on the one hand, we have successfully managed the epidemic and, on the other hand, we have reduced our public debt for many years through our disciplined fiscal policy. As with cohesion policy, it is important, in the case of the Recovery Instrument, to take into account differences in economic development between Member States and the state of the economic sectors affected by the crisis when allocating resources. Poorer Member States should not fund the richer ones. The Eur 750 billion of the Recovery Facility will be raised by the European Commission by borrowing long-term loans. The loan will be repaid by the Member States over a period of 30 years, in proportion to their payments to the EU framework budget. Hungary to repay EUR 7.5 billion of the 750 billion debt with a 1 % contribution rate. Compared to this debt, it is unacceptable that our country would receive a grant of only EUR 8.1 billion, which is barely above its amount.

name: Ondřej KOVAŘÍK
text: Writing. – We must respond decisively, but also responsibly, to the economic crisis caused by the global Covid-19 pandemic. I welcome the fact that the European Commission has finally put forward its proposal, because the funds for restarting the European economy need to be mobilised quickly and properly channeled. Here, however, I must stress that neither the revised multiannual financial framework nor the new economic recovery plan must become an alternative resource for the recovery of national budgets, which have long-term problems primarily unrelated to the current crisis. Budget-responsible states should not be penalised. Likewise, long-term unemployment should not be the main parameter for distributing money. We need to rely on a cohesion policy that we know works. We should focus on investing in sectors and regions where aid will be directed directly to the citizens and businesses most affected, e.g. SMEs in tourism and linked sectors. Likewise, we know that the car or transport sectors are among the most affected – let us support them in a way that is in line with the european Union's policies and direction, so that we try to turn the current economic crisis into an opportunity for further development in all respects. We think of regions at risk of socio-economic transit. Let us help traditional sectors, but let us also focus on innovation and digital technologies.

name: Elżbieta KRUK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – EU countries have faced serious and unexpected challenges due to the actions taken by governments in relation to sars-cov-2 virus. Today, economies are gradually being launched and consideration should be given to the shape of the 2021-2027 MFF so that this framework is ambitious enough and contributes to the recovery of the European economy.  The European agricultural sector has played a key role in ensuring food security. It therefore seems unfortunate that the future of agriculture is still under threat. The number of farms and the number of farmers is decreasing and the population of farmers is ageing. In addition, farmers face the need to meet higher, costly climate requirements in view of the Green Deal targets.  Aid is necessary, but there is a risk of creating new disparities and weakening the existing contribution of cohesion and rural development policy. We must not allow our competitiveness of certain regions and agricultural sectors to increase significantly compared to others. The budgetary proposal for a common agricultural policy put forward by the European Commission does not guarantee a sufficiently secure future for European agriculture: it is un ambitious and insufficient.  In addition, the Objectives of the Green Deal contribute to widening the competitiveness gap between certain regions of the EU. The Union has full responsibility for the agricultural sector. Strengthening the common agricultural policy must become the main pillar of cooperation on the future shape of the CAP. Otherwise, the sector and thus the food security of Europeans will be at risk.

name: Julie LECHANTEUX
text: In writing. The economic recovery plan, presented by the European Commission to deal with the crisis caused by the COVID-19 pandemic, is largely insufficient in scope and completely wrong in its method. The current economic situation is much worse than expected. This is a total and unprecedented crisis, and in this context the European Union is the big absentee.  Today, more than ever, division within the Union is the rule. It's the reign of everyone for themselves. The structure of this Union needs to be thoroughly reviewed, following a model based on a European alliance of nations to save Europe from the European Union.  The proof, if any were needed, is that in the face of the Franco-German proposal there is on the one hand the opposition of the four so-called "frugal" countries (some of which are actually champions of tax optimisation), and on the other hand, the Eastern countries, which will try to safeguard the European subsidies from which they benefit, particularly through agricultural and cohesion policy. I recall here that France and a net contributor to the EU. As a creditor of the Union, it therefore has a say more than any other state.

name: Margarida MARQUES
text: in writing. – The EC proposal for an Economic and Social Recovery Plan and the updating of the proposal for a Multiannual Financial Framework 2021/2027 responds to requests from the European Parliament: - The creation of a Recovery Fund, with the EC mobilising this fund in the markets and allocating it to Member States, in a mechanism for pooling responsibilities; - Distribute this fund on the basis of more grants than loans; - The possibility of this fund being already available this year.  Only then will the EU be able to build a European response to the impact of the crisis on people's lives, economies and state public accounts. It continues to advocate political priorities such as the Green Deal or the Digital Transition. It introduces new priorities such as resetting the Internal Market, creating a health programme, supporting strategic enterprises or promoting the resilience of strategic value chains, while increasing cohesion funding and pillar II - CAP.  On the other hand, it is for the Member States to present, in their full rights, national recovery plans. The European Parliament will continue to be hit by a european and immediate response to the crisis and a robust 7-year MFF that meets European ambition.  That's the only way you're going to give your consent.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – The ‘Next Generation EU’ recovery plan unveiled today proves that the EU acts decisively when it comes to helping European citizens and businesses. Despite there being some opposition to the use of grants for recovery, the Commission’s proposal is bold because it includes EUR 500 billion in grants. The funds will be allocated using different programmes, some of which will be managed directly by Brussels, while others by the Member States themselves. Anyone who has been affected by the crisis can make use of this ambitious plan – SMEs and big businesses, state and local institutions and start-ups, medical and educational institutions, etc. The important thing is that we are not looking to restore the pre-COVID-19 situation but to place a new emphasis on recovery through new technologies, digitalisation, sustainable environmental policies and measures, and ensuring the sustainability and independence of key sectors of our economy. In other words, this is a plan for economic growth which aims for the EU to be more competitive with China and the US in two years than it was before the pandemic.

name: Beata MAZUREK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. " This year's 70th anniversary of the Schuman Declaration is an excellent time for reflection on the functioning of the community. At a time when Europe is facing its biggest crisis since World War II, we must return to its roots and the fundamental values of its founding fathers.  Thank you very much to the President for her enthusiastic and positive speech. We all know how important it is to quickly implement a robust recovery package in order to put the European economy back on its feet and support the millions of European citizens affected by the crisis. However, we must not forget to respect the dissuased views of its members. We must reject prejudices and stereotypes and do not resent the Member States that have taken matters into their own hands and effectively mastered the pandemic in its first phase. There needs to be a discussion on deep reform of the EU, and it needs to be returned after the crisis. The President is drawing up a vision for the next generation of the European Union, based on m.in. on the pursuit of ecological and digital transformation, but do we know what Europe will look like in a few months? What if the pandemic returns in the autumn with double force, how will we be prepared for it? Europe needs a repair for now! Sensitive sectors of the economy must return to Europe with production. Decisions taken in a spirit of responsibility and solidarity must apply to all EU citizens.

name: Leszek MILLER
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I welcome the draft Union budget presented today by the Commission together with the plan for the reconstruction of Europe. The updated budget is projected to increase to 2% of EU GNI and amount to EUR 1.1 trillion. The Reconstruction Fund is planned at EUR 750 billion. This is certainly more than proposed by France and Germany (EUR 500 billion), but still much less than requested by Parliament in its resolution of 15 May (EUR 2 trillion).  In this context, difficult negotiations between The Member States in the Council should undoubtedly be expected, but I am convinced that Parliament will be principled in its efforts to maintain the planned expenditure at a level that corresponds at least to the proposal put forward by the Commission. He will probably use the key Treaty power of the budgetary procedure (consent) for this purpose.  The Commission Communication also highlights the proposed way of financing the enlarged budget and the Reconstruction Fund. It is planned not to raise GNI-based membership fees, but to issue common bonds guaranteed by the EU budget with a 30-year maturity for that purpose, as well as to establish new sources of own revenue, including a financial transaction tax and a digital tax.  I believe that increasing the Union's budgetary and fiscal capacity is moving in the right direction. This should be one of the topics of in-depth discussion at the forthcoming conference on the future of Europe.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. - The European Commission's proposal for a European economic recovery plan is reasonable under the current circumstances and taking into account all risks. EUR 750 billion is designed not just for subsidies and for patching holes, but for environmentally friendly and innovative investments to make the European Union competitive in the world after the crisis. The European single market must recover, and Europe's four major freedoms must also be fully restored. In addition, it is very important that the shock caused by the current crisis does not create major tensions and inconsistencies in relations between EU countries. I see that this recovery plan will help to alleviate and prevent them. This is therefore a European plan, and in the current situation it is an important solution to ensure a strong Europe for the post-crisis times. And a strong Europe is in Estonia's immediate vital interest.

name: Lídia PEREIRA
text: in writing. – The European Commission's proposal for the Recovery Fund is an appropriate response, in the financial dimension, to the challenge of relaunching the European economy.  The 'Next Generation EU' model for funding this Fund is ambitious and corresponds to the demand for solidarity that this crisis determines. I hope that the process of institution of this Fund and its instruments will be swift and effective, with the participation of the European Parliament in order to ensure the democratic nature of this response. We cannot waste any more time and we hope that all European institutions and national governments are committed to the operationalisation of these mechanisms.  I advocate a reform of the European Union's own resources system that increases its limit, streamlines existing resources and creates new and innovative Union revenues, in line with strategic objectives. I welcome the readiness for temporary changes, but I hope it will be an example for a fundamental reform in the near future.  The Recovery Fund calls for a strengthening of the Multiannual Financial Framework and I hope that this effort will result in additional added value, not harming other European programmes and the integrity of the European Structural and Investment Funds.

name: Alfred SANT
text: in writing. – One welcomes the objectives and thrust of the EU recovery package, aimed at relaunching the European economy in the wake of the COVID—19 pandemic. The highlight of this package is the Recovery Fund. The proposal that a large percentage of the funding will be in grants is positive. Its integration into the Multiannual Financial Framework also makes sense. Still the question remains: will the proposed rise of the GNI Own Resources ceiling be enough to cover the envisaged requirements? Some economic forecasts seem to make this quite doubtful. Then more crudely: who will exactly benefit from the envisaged recovery plan? Will the multiple goals that are inbuilt into its proposed design skew benefits towards particular regions or sectors, at the expense of others? For instance: in response to Green Deal exigencies, significant resources will apply to the promotion of clean energy applications, like the creation of a million charging stations for electric cars. Naturally producers of the latter, mainly located in two Member States, will benefit most from this. Care will have to be taken to ensure that the recovery plan, positive as it is, does not serve to widen instead of narrow existing divergences between different regions of the Union.

name: Sylwia SPUREK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The crisis caused by COVID-19 highlighted the Union's weaknesses in the protection of fundamental human rights, proving that it is time not only for a more principled approach to Union law and policies, but also for its new competences. The crisis caused by the pandemic has affected people belonging to social groups already exposed to discrimination, exclusion, violence.  Women experiencing domestic violence are now even more vulnerable to it. Pregnant and nascent women have poorer access to perinatal care. In some countries, LGBTI people are denied a fundamental right to dignity under the guise of fighting the coronavirus. People with disabilities are affected by deficiencies in the health system and deprived of the necessary treatment and rehabilitation.  This situation clearly shows that the lack of coordinated Union action and uniform guarantees of rights can lead governments to abuses in the area of fundamental rights. The Union must take responsibility for the most vulnerable groups in society and ensure that the recovery plan also takes into account their rights. I have repeatedly stressed that we can no longer postpone the ratification by the Union of the Istanbul Convention, the effective implementation of the CRPD and the adoption of a horizontal equality directive. We must remember that the EU is not only a political and economic body, but also a social body, and that equality of people and uniform guarantees of their rights should be our standards.

name: Riho TERRAS
text: Writing. – I am convinced that the Recovery Facility is a necessary instrument for exiting the crisis. This will provide the necessary strength for the MULTIANNUAL FINANCIAL FRAMEWORK. It is essential that there is strict control over the use of money borrowed from the markets and that the European Parliament also participates in monitoring. In my opinion, it is necessary for Parliament to be closely involved in the whole budgetary process, because it is the only Pan-European set that has a popular mandate. Money for economic recovery must be targeted at a targeted basis and bring high added value. It would be unacceptable for all of us to be able to patch holes in the holes caused by poor and irresponsible political decisions. Conservative monetary policy must be honoured and we must take the debt relief to our children and grandchildren with the utmost seriousness. This is certainly not in line with the principles of responsible policy. Today, the European Commission has not yet clearly indicated from which sources loans from the markets will be serviced. Surely both the crucial representative bodies of the Member States of the European Union and we, the Members of the European Parliament, have the right and the duty to know all the necessary details before making important decisions. I am convinced that, in order to revive the economy and increase Europe's competitiveness, it is necessary, like the Green Treaty, to emphasise the digital revolution. This is one of the most important factors influencing Europe's competitiveness today and in the future.

name: Edina TÓTH
text: Writing. – From a Hungarian point of view, it is a success that the proposal is that the new Recovery Instrument would not be created at the expense of regional development programmes and the common agricultural policy. At the same time, two thirds of the Member States, including Hungary, are well founded on the new proposal, which is almost unchanged from the previous proposals. Hungary has achieved outstanding economic success in recent years and is at the forefront of the management of the epidemic. It would be unjustified if we could not benefit sufficiently from recovery resources because, on the one hand, we have successfully managed the epidemic and, on the other hand, we have reduced our public debt for many years through our disciplined fiscal policy. As with cohesion policy, it is important, in the case of the Recovery Instrument, to take into account differences in economic development between Member States and the state of the economic sectors affected by the crisis when allocating resources. Poorer Member States should not fund the richer ones. The Eur 750 billion of the Recovery Facility will be raised by the European Commission by borrowing long-term loans. The loan will be repaid by the Member States over a period of 30 years, in proportion to their payments to the EU framework budget. Hungary to repay EUR 7.5 billion of the 750 billion debt with a 1 % contribution rate. Compared to this debt, it is unacceptable that hungary would receive a grant of just over EUR 8.1 billion

name: Bettina VOLLATH
text: Writing. – The COVID-19 pandemic has led the European Union into the deepest crisis in its existence, as we are now heading for the biggest recession in over 70 years. In order to overcome this crisis and save the European economy, we now need far-reaching investment. The reconstruction plan presented today is an important building block. It makes it clear that this crisis is also an opportunity. An opportunity for a stronger, more ecological and more united – in short, a better Europe of the future. For this opportunity to become a reality, all Member States must now play their part and support this proposal so that it can be implemented. We must finally move away from the wrong and harmful austerity policy after the last crisis, towards a European solution based on solidarity. Nevertheless, the reconstruction plan can only be the first step. Europe will need more aid packages in the future, and in order to finance all this, the EU finally needs more own resources. Plastic tax, CO2 tax and digital tax are just a few of the many possibilities. We must finally ask those companies that pollute our environment and those that smuggle their income past the treasury to pay. Because it must be they who end up providing funding for these programmes and not, as so often before, European citizens.

name: Alexandr VONDRA
text: Writing. – We can certainly agree that what we have seen in Europe over the last three months has been exceptional. And exceptional situations require exceptional means. But, as we have seen many times in Europe, too often exceptions become rules, and paper can withstand everything. It is therefore good to say from the outset what our red lines are: no permanent debt mutualisation, no swelling of the European budget and no taxes at European level. Aid is only one-off and limited, and no one should be punished for being responsibly managed in the long term and taking real account of its options, for example when it comes to joining the euro area. Let us also take into account that there is an order of order of greater risk of corruption than cohesion funds: rapid financial assistance after the crisis will automatically lead to a reduction in some control mechanisms in the redistribution of money. Even in the case of cohesion funds, they sometimes ended up in various dubious enterprises, such as the Czech Prime Minister or even the Italian mafia, requiring much more time and bureaucracy. It is important not to sacrifice control mechanisms and to see that money is not enriched by well-known politicians or firms that have been loss-making for most of their existence. It is important not to sacrifice the thrift and auance of megalomania. It's important not to sacrifice common sense.

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: Writing. – Europe is facing an unprecedented crisis in all Member States for the first time since World War II. European citizens are not satisfied with the measures taken so far at European level and expect increased powers, greater solidarity and a stronger response to the crisis from the EU. The new Recovery Fund is an ambitious project to support the Union with increased resources, which will be made available mainly through grants. However, significant support and immediate disbursement of money should be provided for the tourism sector, which has been hardest hit by the pandemic. Tourism, which contributes around 11% to European GDP and accounts for 12% of EMPLOYMENT in the EU, loses around EUR 1 billion in 2015. This is due to the pandemic. The situation is particularly difficult in many EU countries which are key tourist destinations, such as Greece, where the tourism sector indirectly contributes more than 20% to the Greek economy. The Greek government has already taken important steps to support the sector, but the answer should not be given individually by the Member States but by the EU as a whole. Let us not let our citizens down!

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. – The proposal for a European Union recovery package presented by the President of the European Commission, Ursula von der Leyen, constitutes a disruptive development in the typology of the Union's responses to systemic crises. It is a strong and supportive proposal. The extent of the crisis is not unrelated to this, the perception of citizens that only a coordinated response can deal with it and the adoption by the European Parliament by a large majority of resolutions that give the support of the direct representatives of the peoples of Europe to developments.  Investing in a green, digital and resilient Europe, adding to the Multiannual Financing Framework, own resources and the creation of a €750 billion Recovery Fund, using common debt issues and allocated €500 billion (66% of that fund) through grants, is a potentially robust response, which the Council should adopt as soon as possible, so that the European Parliament's negotiation and consent procedures and specific regulation allow resources to arrive as soon as possible where they are needed.

name: Katarina BARLEY
text: I declare the session of the European Parliament adjourned.
